(Mary Our Hope) }} [[Image:Keough Seal.jpg|thumb|right|Archbishop Keough's coat of arms.]] '''Francis Patrick Keough''' (December 30, 1890 – December 8, 1961) was an [[United States|American]] clergyman of the [[Roman Catholic Church]]. He served as [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence|Bishop of Providence]] (1934-1947) and [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Baltimore|Archbishop of Baltimore]] (1947-1961). ==Biography== Francis Keough was born in [[New Britain, Connecticut]], the second and youngest son of Patrick and Margaret (née Ryan) Keough.{{cite news|work=[[Cathedral of Mary Our Queen]]|title=Archbishop Francis P. Keough: Builder of a New Cathedral (1947-1961)|url=http://www.cathedralofmary.org/history/archbishops4.htm}} His parents were [[Ireland|Irish]] immigrants, and his father died when Francis was only five years old. He received his early education at the parochial school of [http://www.saintmarynb.org/ St. Mary's Church] in his native city, and began his studies for the [[Priesthood (Catholic Church)|priesthood]] at [[St. Thomas Seminary]] in [[Bloomfield, Connecticut|Bloomfield]].{{cite news|work=[[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Baltimore]]|title=Most Rev. Francis Patrick Keough|url=http://www.archbalt.org/our-history/ordinaries-detail.cfm?customel_datapageid_999=2207}} In 1911, he was sent to the Grand Seminary of Saint-Sulpice in [[Issy-les-Moulineaux]], [[France]]. He returned home following the outbreak of [[World War I]], and completed his theological studies at [[St. Bernard's School of Theology and Ministry|St. Bernard's Seminary]] in [[Rochester, New York|Rochester]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. On June 10, 1916, Keough was [[Holy Orders|ordained]] a priest for the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hartford|Diocese of Hartford]] by Bishop [[John Joseph Nilan]].{{cite news|work=Catholic-Hierarchy.org|title=Archbishop Francis Patrick Keough|url=http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/bkeough.html}} His first assignment was as a [[curate]] at [http://www.archdioceseofhartford.org/cgi-bin/history.pl?textdata=187 St. Rose Church] in [[Meriden, Connecticut|Meriden]], where he remained until becoming private secretary to Bishop Nilan in 1919. He also served as diocesan director of the [[Society for the Propagation of the Faith]], assistant [[Chancellor (ecclesiastical)|chancellor]], and [[chaplain]] of two institutions. On February 10, 1934, Keough was appointed the fourth [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence|Bishop of Providence]], [[Rhode Island]], by [[Pope Pius XI]]. He received his [[Bishop (Catholic Church)|episcopal]] [[consecration]] on the following May 22 from Archbishop [[Amleto Giovanni Cicognani]], with Archbishop [[John Murray (archbishop)|John Murray]] and Bishop [[James Edwin Cassidy]] serving as [[Consecrator|co-consecrators]]. During his tenure in Providence, the Catholic population of the diocese increased from 325,000 to 425,000, and the number of clergy grew by fifty percent. He also founded a minor seminary, eased tensions between the [[French language|French]]-speaking and [[English language|English]]-speaking members of his congregation, and reduced the heavy financial debts burdening the diocese. On November 29, 1947, Keough was named by [[Pope Pius XII]] to succeed [[Michael Joseph Curley]] as the eleventh [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Baltimore|Archbishop of Baltimore]], [[Maryland]]. He was formally installed in the [[Basilica of the National Shrine of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary|Basilica of the Assumption]] on February 24, 1948. During the fourteen years of his administration, the Catholic population of the archdiocese, the first Catholic see in the United States, grew from 265,000 to 400,000.{{cite news|date=December 9, 1961 |work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Archbishop Francis P. Keough Of Baltimore See Is Dead at 70. Leader of 400,000 Catholics. Assumed Post in 1947. Ex-Bishop of Providence |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9800E3DF153DEF32A2575AC0A9649D946091D6CF}} The new [[Cathedral of Mary Our Queen]] and many new schools, homes, orphanages and other institutions were built. He was a trustee of the Catholic University of America and a member of the [[American Board of Catholic Missions]], and served three terms as chairman of the [[National Catholic Welfare Conference]]. Keough was known as the "Archbishop of the poor" due to his dedication to orphans and the aged.{{cite news|date=1961-12-15|work=[[Time (magazine)|TIME Magazine]]|title=Milestones|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,827111,00.html}} He was named an [[Assistant at the Pontifical Throne]] in 1959. Keough died from [[cerebral thrombosis]], aged 70. ==See also== {{Portal|Catholicism}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Catholic Church hierarchy]] * [[Catholic Church in the United States]] * [[Historical list of the Catholic bishops of the United States]] * [[List of Catholic bishops of the United States]] * [[Lists of patriarchs, archbishops, and bishops]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160101202340/http://w2.vatican.va/content/vatican/en.html Official site of the Holy See] ==Episcopal succession== {{s-start}} {{s-rel|ca}} {{succession box | title=[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence|Bishop of Providence]] | before=[[William A. McVinney]] | years=1934–1947}} {{succession box | title=[[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Baltimore|Archbishop of Baltimore]] | before=[[Michael Joseph Curley]] | after=[[Lawrence Shehan]] | years=1947–1961 }} {{s-end}} {{RC Archdiocese of Baltimore}} {{Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence}} {{Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hartford}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Keough, Francis Patrick}} [[Category:1890 births]] [[Category:1961 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century Roman Catholic archbishops]] [[Category:American Roman Catholic archbishops]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Archbishops of Baltimore]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:Religious leaders from Baltimore]] [[Category:People from New Britain, Connecticut]] [[Category:Roman Catholic bishops of Providence]] [[Category:Deaths from thrombosis]] [[Category:Catholic University of America trustees]] [[Category:Catholics from Connecticut]]

{{Infobox Officeholder |name = Frank Bosworth Brandegee |image = Frank Bosworth Brandegee.jpg |jr/sr1 = United States Senator |state1 = [[Connecticut]] |term_start1 = May 10, 1905 |term_end1 = October 14, 1924 |predecessor1 = [[Orville H. Platt]] |successor1 = [[Hiram Bingham III]] |state2 = [[Connecticut]] |district2 = [[Connecticut's 3rd congressional district|3rd]] |term_start2 = November 4, 1902 |term_end2 = May 10, 1905 |preceded2 = [[Charles Addison Russell|Charles A. Russell]] |succeeded2 = [[Edwin W. Higgins]] |office3 = Member of the [[Connecticut House of Representatives]] |term3 = 1888 |birth_date = {{birth date|1864|7|8}} |birth_place = [[New London, Connecticut|New London]], [[Connecticut]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1924|10|14|1864|7|8}} |death_place = [[Washington, D.C.]] |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] }} '''Frank Bosworth Brandegee''' (July 8, 1864{{spaced ndash}}October 14, 1924) was a [[United States Representative]] and [[United States Senate|Senator]] from [[Connecticut]].
==Early life== Frank Brandegee was born in [[New London, Connecticut]] July 8, 1864. He was the son of [[Augustus Brandegee]], who also served in the United States House.<ref>Yale University, Class of 1885, [https://books.google.com/books?id=6bcvAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA119&dq=frank+brandegee+born+1864&hl=en&sa=X&ei=CA68Up_vB-mfyQGu4YHwBw&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=frank%20brandegee%20born%201864&f=false Quarter-Centenary Record of the Class of 1885, Yale University], 1913, page 119</ref>
He graduated from New London's Bulkeley High School in 1881. He completed his degree at [[Yale College]] in 1885, where he was a member of [[Skull and Bones]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://mssa.library.yale.edu/obituary_record/1859_1924/1924-25.pdf | title=Obituary Record of Graduates of Yale University Deceased during the Year 1924-1925 | accessdate=March 24, 2011 | year=1925 | publisher=Yale University}}</ref>{{rp|1369}} He studied law, and was admitted to the bar in 1888 and practiced in New London.<ref>Norris Galpin Osborn, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ARFh_Sbpg84C&pg=PA54&dq=frank+brandegee+connecticut+speaker&hl=en&sa=X&ei=EQu8UsuHH4LWyQGi2oCQAw&ved=0CF0Q6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=frank%20brandegee%20connecticut%20speaker&f=false Men of Mark in Connecticut], Volume 1, 1906, pages 54-57</ref>
A [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], in 1888 Brandegee served in the [[Connecticut House of Representatives]], and was New London's Corporation Counsel from 1889 to 1893 and 1894 to 1897.<ref>United States Senate Historical Office, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ucYiQfN8zmkC&pg=PA84&dq=frank+brandegee+admitted+bar&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Sgq8Ur-BBeGEyAGM34GYAw&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=frank%20brandegee%20admitted%20bar&f=false Pro Tem: Presidents Pro Tempore of the United States Senate Since 1789], 2008, page 84</ref>
He returned to the Connecticut House in 1899, and served as [[Speaker of the Connecticut House of Representatives|Speaker]]. He served again as New London's Corporation Counsel from 1901 to 1902, when he resigned because he had been elected to Congress.<ref>Samuel Hart, editor, [https://books.google.com/books?id=KSwEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA277&dq=frank+brandegee+connecticut+speaker&hl=en&sa=X&ei=EQu8UsuHH4LWyQGi2oCQAw&ved=0CGIQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=frank%20brandegee%20connecticut%20speaker&f=false Encyclopedia of Connecticut Biography], Volume 4, 1917, page 277</ref>
==U.S. House== Brandegee was elected as a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] to the Fifty-seventh Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the death of [[Charles Addison Russell|Charles A. Russell]]. He was reelected to the Fifty-eighth and Fifty-ninth Congresses and served from November 4, 1902, until May 10, 1905, when he resigned.<ref>Caryn Hannan, editor, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Pd_ETIlgTxgC&pg=PA160&dq=frank+brandegee+charles+russell&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wg68UufoBOeBygGbhYCIDA&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=frank%20brandegee%20charles%20russell&f=false Connecticut Biographical Dictionary], 2008, page 160</ref>
Brandegee was a delegate to several state and national Republican conventions, and was chairman of the [[Connecticut Republican Party]]'s 1904 state convention.<ref>John Tweedy, [https://books.google.com/books?id=VKcJAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA265&lpg=PA265&dq=%22frank+brandegee%22+chairman+convention&source=bl&ots=Hglmr7Pacu&sig=3s9noZ-FcpQj25EHR8eOjqbOfi4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hUW8UvqRHoHCywG7kIHwCw&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22frank%20brandegee%22%20chairman%20convention&f=false A History of the Republican National Conventions from 1856 to 1908], 1910, page 265</ref><ref>William Harrison Taylor, [https://books.google.com/books?id=pwcWAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA206&dq=%22frank+b+brandegee%22+chairman+convention&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HEa8Uu6cJbGyygHqmYDwCg&ved=0CCwQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=%22frank%20b%20brandegee%22%20chairman%20convention&f=false Taylor's Legislative History and Souvenir of Connecticut], 1897, Volume 4, page 206</ref><ref>New York Times, [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1904/05/11/120268400.pdf Connecticut Convention], May 11, 1904</ref>
==U.S. Senate== Brandegee resigned from the House to accept election to the U.S. Senate, filling the vacancy caused by the death of [[Orville H. Platt]].<ref>Connecticut General Assembly, [https://books.google.com/books?id=EwIiAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA933&lpg=PA933&dq=brandegee+senate+death+%22orville+h+platt%22&source=bl&ots=HkkgSl4oWC&sig=uwrhzGn8iG7Vlf0jWNukNgqV-IU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Z0e8UuuWI9TyyAG4yYDQCw&ved=0CD0Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=brandegee%20senate%20death%20%22orville%20h%20platt%22&f=false Journal of the Senate of the State of Connecticut], 1905, page 933</ref>
He was reelected in 1908, 1914, and 1920, and served from May 10, 1905 until his death.<ref>Charles F. Ritter, Jon L. Wakelyn, American Legislative Leaders, 1850-1910, 1989, page 72</ref>
A staunch "Old Guard" conservative, Brandegee opposed women's suffrage, America's participation in the [[League of Nations]], and most other measures of the time that were considered liberal or progressive.<ref>Carole Nichols, [https://books.google.com/books?id=aiKx3Q74lsEC&pg=PA39&dq=brandegee+opposed+%22league+of+nations%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=eUi8Upf8NqOiyAHxuIDgCw&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=brandegee%20opposed%20%22league%20of%20nations%22&f=false Votes and More for Women: Suffrage and After in Connecticut], 2013, page 39</ref><ref>Cecelia Bucki, [https://books.google.com/books?id=5sqULah9Jj0C&pg=PA215&dq=brandegee+opposed+women's+suffrage&hl=en&sa=X&ei=L0m8Ut2tOab7yAGYhICoDw&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=brandegee%20opposed%20women's%20suffrage&f=false Bridgeport's Socialist New Deal, 1915-36], 2001, page 215</ref><ref>Ruth O'Brien, [https://books.google.com/books?id=wVrwqAAJmZoC&pg=PA227&lpg=PA227&dq=frank+brandegee+%22old+guard%22&source=bl&ots=RasTNtkygT&sig=tA1c4LLUvvwh6a1MkjKQxD2FBaY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Vgi-UqLuIMTjsAS2_oD4DA&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=frank%20brandegee%20%22old%20guard%22&f=false Workers' Paradox: The Republican Origins of New Deal Labor Policy, 1886-1935], 1998, page 227</ref> In [[1920 Republican National Convention|1920]] Brandegee was also one of the chief promoters of [[Warren G. Harding]] for [[President of the United States|President]].<ref>Stephen Graubard, [https://books.google.com/books?id=P077YZm09wsC&pg=PT261&dq=brandegee+supporter+harding+president&hl=en&sa=X&ei=f0m8UvvgNqXhyQGv_YCYDA&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=brandegee%20supporter%20harding%20president&f=false The Presidents: The Transformation of the American Presidency from Theodore Roosevelt to Barack Obama], 2009</ref><ref>Laton McCartney, [https://books.google.com/books?id=aegJqkF3ae8C&pg=PA24&lpg=PA24&dq=frank+brandegee+%22old+guard%22&source=bl&ots=Ofi9BwDMrG&sig=69FfDLU5m_Swi-ONNKiyJ5bORnI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Vgi-UqLuIMTjsAS2_oD4DA&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q&f=false The Teapot Dome Scandal: How Big Oil Bought the Harding White House and Tried to Steal the Country], 2009, page 24</ref>
In the Senate he was Chairman of the following committees: Interoceanic Canals ([[62nd United States Congress|Sixty-second Congress]]); Panama ([[62nd United States Congress|Sixty-second Congress]]); Pacific Railroads ([[63rd United States Congress|Sixty-third]] through [[65th United States Congress|Sixty-fifth Congresses]]); Library ([[66th United States Congress|Sixty-sixth]] and [[67th United States Congress|Sixty-seventh]] Congresses); and Judiciary ([[68th United States Congress|Sixty-eighth]] Congress).<ref>Lawrence P. Ardis, Party leaders in Congress, 1789-2002, 2002, page 45</ref>
Brandegee was [[President pro tempore of the United States Senate|President pro tempore]] during several sessions of the Senate in the [[62nd United States Congress|Sixty-second Congress]] (1911 to 1913).<ref>Robert C. Byrd, [https://books.google.com/books?id=PeHByMYxVm8C&pg=PA652&dq=brandegee+senate+president+pro+tempore&hl=en&sa=X&ei=50q8UtKqOo2FyQGvj4HICQ&ved=0CEIQ6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=brandegee%20senate%20president%20pro%20tempore&f=false Senate, 1789-1989: Historical Statistics, 1789-1992], Volume 4, 1993, page 652</ref>
==Death and burial== Brandegee never married and had no children.<ref>United Press, The Southeast Missourian, [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1893&dat=19241014&id=cSYrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jdMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2362,1895764 Senator Brandegee Found Dead at Home], October 14, 1924</ref>
He committed [[suicide]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] on October 14, 1924, inhaling fumes from a [[Gas lighting|gas light]] in a seldom used bathroom on the third floor of his home.<ref>Pine Plains Register, [http://fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%206/Pine%20Plaines%20NY%20Register%20Herald/Pine%20Plaines%20NY%20Register%20Herald%201924-1925%20Grayscale/Pine%20Plaines%20NY%20Register%20Herald%201924-1925%20Grayscale%20-%200368.pdf Brandegee Dead by Gas], October 15, 1924</ref> According to published accounts, he was in ill health and had lost most of his fortune through bad investments.<ref>Time Magazine, [http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,728765,00.html Political Notes: De Mortuis], January 4, 1926</ref> Press reports at the time indicated that he left his chauffeur a suicide note and $100, with another $100 for two other household servants.<ref>Bridgeport Telegram, Brandegee's Death Blamed on Isolation and Financial Loss, October 15, 1924</ref><ref>St. Petersburg Evening Independent, [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19241015&id=g6MLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=51QDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4597,2300834 Financial Losses Cause Senator to Turn on Gas], October 15, 1924</ref>
He was interred at [[Cedar Grove Cemetery (New London, Connecticut)|Cedar Grove Cemetery]] in New London.<ref>Thomas E. Spencer, [https://books.google.com/books?id=eLWao2lIGTEC&pg=PA117&dq=%22brandegee,+frank%22+%22cedar+grove%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=zgm8UpOsMMblyAGOqIDwBw&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22brandegee%2C%20frank%22%20%22cedar%20grove%22&f=false Where They're Buried], 1998, page 117</ref>
==See also== *[[List of United States Congress members who died in office (1900–49)]]

[[File:FSL Lego minifigure analogy.png|thumb|480x480px|''Fig. 1'' A structural analogy of a Lego Minifigure to a chemical [[Space-filling model|space filling models]] of an FSL construct. The FSL construct is a [[peptide]]-based partially carboxymethylated oligoglycine (CMG2) spacer with 1,2- dioleoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphoethanolamine ([[Phospholipid#Phospholipid derivatives|DOPE]]) lipid.
© Kode Biotech Limited ]] '''Function-Spacer-Lipid (FSL) Kode constructs''' (Kode Technology) are [[Amphiphile|amphiphatic]], water [[wikt:dispersible|dispersible]] biosurface engineering constructs that can be used to engineer the surface of [[cell (biology)|cell]]s, [[virus]]es and organisms, or to modify solutions and non-biological surfaces with bioactives.<ref name="Blake2011" /><ref name="Korchagina2012" /><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Synthetic glycolipid-like constructs as tools for glycobiology research, diagnostics, and as potential therapeutics|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1134/S0006297915070068|journal = Biochemistry (Moscow)|date = 2015-07-16|issn = 0006-2979|pages = 857–871|volume = 80|issue = 7|doi = 10.1134/S0006297915070068|language = en|first = E. Y.|last = Korchagina|first2 = S. M.|last2 = Henry}}</ref> FSL Kode constructs spontaneously and stably incorporate into cell membranes. FSL Kode constructs with all these aforementioned features are also known as Kode Constructs.<ref name="Blake2011" /> The process of modifying surfaces with FSL Kode constructs is known as "koding" and the resultant "koded" [[Cell (biology)|cell]]s,<ref name="Blake2011" /> [[virus]]es and [[liposome]]s are respectively known as [[kodecytes]],<ref name="Blake2011" /><ref name="Henry2009" /> and [[kodevirions]]<ref name="Blake2011" /><ref name="Hadac2011" />.
==Technology description==
All [[Cell membrane|living surfaces]] are decorated with a diverse range of complex molecules, which are key modulators of [[Cell signaling|chemical communications]] and other functions such as protection, [[Cell adhesion|adhesion]], [[infectivity]], [[apoptosis]], etc. Functional-Spacer-Lipid (FSL) Kode constructs can be [[Chemical synthesis|synthesized]] to mimic the bioactive components present on biological surfaces, and then re-present them in novel ways.<ref name="Blake2011" /><ref name="Korchagina2012" />
The architecture of an FSL Kode construct, as implicit in the name, consists of three components - a functional head group, a spacer, and a lipid tail.<ref name=":0" /> This structure is analogous to a [[Lego minifigure]] in that, they have three structural components, with each component having a separate purpose.<ref name="Blake2011" /><ref name="Korchagina2012" /> In the examples shown in all the figures, a Lego '[[minifig]]' has been used for the analogy. However, it should be appreciated that this is merely a representation and the true structural similarity is significantly varied between Lego minifigures and FSL Kode constructs ''(fig 1)''. The functional group of an FSL is equivalent to a Lego minifigure head, with both being at the extremity and carrying the character functional components. The spacer of the FSL is equivalent to the body of the Lego minifigure and the arms on the minifigure are representative of substitutions which may be engineered into the chemical makeup of the spacer. The lipid of the FSL anchors it to lipid membranes and gives the FSL construct its [[amphiphile|amphiphatic]] nature which can cause it to self-assemble. Because the lipid tail can act directly as an anchor it is analogous to the legs of a Lego minifigure.
==Flexible design== The functional group, the spacer and the lipid tail components of the FSL Kode construct can each be individually designed resulting in FSL Kode constructs with specific biological functions.<ref name="Korchagina2012" /> The functional head group is usually the bioactive component of the construct and the various spacers and lipids influence and effect its presentation, orientation and location on a surface. Critical to the definition of an FSL Kode construct is the requirement to be [[Dispersion (chemistry)|dispersible]] in water, and spontaneously and stably incorporate into cell membranes. Other lipid [[Bioconjugation|bioconjugates]] that include components similar to FSLs but do not have these features are not termed as Function-Spacer-Lipid Kode constructs.<ref name="Korchagina2012" />
===Functional groups<ref name=":0" />=== [[File:FSL Lego features.png|thumb|527x527px|''Fig. 2'' Diagram showing the features of the function-spacer-lipid construct of a [[kodecyte]], using the analogy of a Lego minifigure. As indicated in the figure, the function group analogous to the minifigures head can be arranged in different substances, the spacer analogous to the body of the minifigure (including the arms) can have a variety of different features, and the lipid or minifigure legs can be a variety of different lipids. Together the three components of function, spacer & lipid represent the FSL construct.
© Kode Biotech Limited ]] A large range of functional groups have already been made into FSL Kode constructs. These include: * '''Carbohydrates''' – ranging from [[monosaccharide]]s to [[polysaccharide]]s and including blood group [[antigens]],<ref name="Blake2011" /><ref name="Korchagina2012" /><ref name="Frame2007" /><ref name="Harrison2010" /><ref name="Georgakopoulos2011" /><ref name="Oliver2011a" /><ref name="Oliver2011b" /><ref name="Hult2012" /><ref name="Henry2012b" /> [[hyaluronic acid]] [[oligomers]] and [[sialic acid]] residues<ref name="Korchagina2012" /> * '''Peptide/protein''' – ranging from single [[amino acid]]s<ref name="Georgakopoulos2011" /><ref name="Heathcote2010" /><ref name="Nadarajan2011" /><ref name="Henry2011" /> to [[proteins]] as large as [[antibodies]]<ref name="Blake2011" /> * '''Labels''' – including [[fluorophores]],<ref name="Blake2011" /><ref name="Korchagina2012" /><ref name="Hadac2011" /><ref name="Oliver2011a" /><ref name="Oliver2011b" /><ref name="Lan2012" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = Incorporation of fluorescein conjugated function-spacer-lipid constructs into the red blood cell membrane facilitates detection of labeled cells for the duration of ex-vivo storage|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022175916300023|journal = Journal of Immunological Methods|doi = 10.1016/j.jim.2016.01.003|first = Katrina K.|last = Ki|first2 = Robert L.|last2 = Flower|first3 = Helen M.|last3 = Faddy|first4 = Melinda M.|last4 = Dean|date = Jan 7, 2016|volume=429|pages=66–70}}</ref> [[radioisotope]]s,<ref name="Blake2011" /><ref name="Hadac2011" /> [[biotin]],<ref name="Blake2011" /><ref name="Korchagina2012" /><ref name="Oliver2011a" /><ref name="Oliver2011b" /> etc. * '''Other''' – chemical [[Moiety (chemistry)|moieties]] such as [[maleimide]],<ref name="Henry2011" /><ref name="Henry2012a" /> [[Click chemistry|click]] residues, [[Polyethylene glycol|PEG]], charged compounds ''Note 1: Multimeric – the presentation of the F residue can be as [[multimer]]s with controlled spacing and be variable.''
''Note 2: Mass – the mass that can be anchored by an FSL Kode constructs can range from 200 to >1x10<sup>6</sup> [[Dalton (unit)|Da]]''
===Spacers<ref name=":0" />=== The spacer is an integral part of the FSL Kode construct and gives it several important characteristics including water [[Dispersion (chemistry)|dispersibility]].<ref name="Korchagina2012" /> * '''Length''' – the spacer can be varied in length, for example 1.9 nm (Ad), 7.2 nm (CMG2), 11.5 nm (CMG4),<ref name="Korchagina2012" /> allowing for enhanced presentation of Functional groups at the biosurface. * '''Optimizes 'F' presentation''' – The presentation of the bioactive (functional group) on a spacer reduces [[steric hindrance]] and increases the bioactive surfaces exposed and available for interactions * '''Rigidity''' – the spacer can be modified to be either flexible or rigid depending upon desired characteristics * '''Substitutions''' (represented by the leaves on the stalk) – the spacer can be modified both in [[charge (chemistry)|charge]], and [[Chemical polarity|polarity]]. * '''Branches''' – usually the spacer is linear, but it can also be branched including specific spacing of the branches to optimize presentation and interaction of the F group. * '''Inert''' – important to the design of FSL Kode constructs is the biologically inert nature of the spacer. Importantly this feature means the S-L components of the constructs are unreactive with undiluted serum. Consequently, the constructs are compatible ''[[in vivo]]'' use, and can improve diagnostic assay sensitivity by allowing for the use of undiluted serum.
===Lipids<ref name=":0" />=== The [[lipid]] tail is essential for enabling [[lipid membrane]] insertion and retention but also for giving the construct [[amphiphile|amphiphilic]] characteristics that enable [[hydrophilic]] surface coating (due to formation of [[bilipid layer]]s). Different [[Lipid bilayer|membrane lipids]] that can be used to create FSLs have different membrane physiochemical characteristics and thus can affect biological function of the FSL. Lipids in FSL Kode constructs include:<ref name="Korchagina2012" /> * '''Diacyl/diakyl''' e.g. DOPE * '''Sterols''' e.g. cholesterol * '''Ceramides'''
== Optimising functional group (F) presentation == {{multiple image <!-- Essential parameters --> | align = right | direction = horizontal | width = 300
<!-- Image 1 --> | image1 = Comparison between normal and FSL antigen presentation in immunoassays.svg | width1 = | alt1 = | caption1 = ''Fig. 3'' Diagram comparing the presentation of antigens in immunoassays between a typical direct attachment and in a function-spacer-lipid (by analogy to a flower). Upper image shows the antigen (flower head) presented in a variety of formats directly on a solid surface. The construct attaches randomly to the solid surface. Lower image shows the same antigen (flower head) presented in optimal orientation as an FSL construct with a spacer (stalk) holding it away from the solid surface. The lipid tail (roots) causes the construct to attach to the solid surface.
<!-- Image 2 --> | image2 = SL variation.svg | width2 = | alt2 = | caption2 = ''Fig. 4'' Combinations of different spacers, lipids and other modifications can be used to optimise the functionality of the function group on the FSL construct. In all diagrams, the same functional group is represented by the sunflower head. The first four examples show [[monomer]]ic presentation of F, with the first example representing the short 1.9nm (Ad) spacer (the flower stalk). The second and fourth with the longer stalks (spacers) representing the CMG2 7.2nm spacer and CMG4 11.5nm spacers respectively. The second and third constructs have the same spacers, but the lipid tail of the third construct is [[cholesterol]], rather than [[Phospholipid#Phospholipid derivatives|DOPE]]. The last three examples all based on CMG2 spacers (stalks), with a DOPE lipid tail (roots) are multimeric presentations of F. The first of these is a simple duplication of the F group, while the following has an additional spacer between the F groups. The final construct is a cluster presentation. }}
One of the important functions of an FSL construct is that it can optimise the presentation of [[antigen]]s, both on cell surfaces and solid-phase membranes. This optimisation is achieved primarily by the spacer, and secondarily by the lipid tail. In a typical [[immunoassay]], the antigen is deposited directly onto the [[microplate]] surface and binds to the surface either in a random fashion, or in a preferred orientation depending on the residues present on the surface of this antigen. Usually this deposition process is uncontrolled. In contrast, the FSL Kode construct bound to a microplate presents the antigen away from the surface in an orientation with a high level of exposure to the environment. Furthermore, typical immunoassays use recombinant [[peptide]]s rather than discrete peptide antigens. As the recombinant peptide is many times bigger than the [[epitope]] of interest, a lot of undesired and unwanted peptide sequences are also represented on the microplate. These additional sequences may include unwanted microbial related sequences (as determined by a [[BLAST]] analysis) that can cause issues of low level cross-reactivity. Often the mechanism by which an immunoassay is able to overcome this low level activity is to dilute the serum so that the low level microbial reactive [[antibodies]] are not seen, and only high-level specific antibodies result in an interpretable result. In contrast, FSL Kode constructs usually use specifically selected peptide fragments (up to 40 amino acids),<ref name="Henry2011" /><ref name="Henry2012a" /> thereby overcoming cross-reactivity with microbial sequences, and allowing for the use of undiluted [[serum (blood)|serum]] (which increases [[Sensitivity and specificity|sensitivity]]).
The F component can be further enhanced by presentation of it in [[multimeric]] formats and with specific spacing. The four types of multimeric format include linear repeating units, linear repeating units with spacing, clusters, and branching ''(Fig. 4)''.
== Mechanisms of interaction ==
{{multiple image <!-- Essential parameters --> | align = right | direction = horizontal | width = 220 <!-- Image 3 --> | image1 = FSL Micelle.png | width1 = | alt1 = | caption1 = ''Fig. 5a'' Schematic cross-sectional slice of FSL [[micelle]]s. FSL construct by nature of its composition in possessing both [[hydrophobic]] and [[hydrophilic]] regions is [[amphiphilic]] (or amphiphathic). This characteristic determines the way in which the construct will interact with surfaces. When present in a solution they may form simple micelles or adopt more complex bilayer structures
<!-- Image 1 --> | image2 = Hydrophobic surface FSL coating.svg | width2 = | alt2 = | caption2 = ''Fig. 5b'' [[Hydrophobic|Hydrophobic surface]] FSL coating. The hydrophobic lipid tail of an FSL construct will interact and anchor FSL constructs directly onto hydrophobic surfaces. <!-- Image 2 --> | image3 = Hydrophilic surface FSL coating.svg | width3 = | alt3 = | caption3 = ''Fig. 5c'' [[Hydrophilic|Hydrophilic surface]] FSL coating. The [[hydrophobe|hydrophobic]] lipid tail of an FSL construct will not interact directly with hydrophilic surfaces. Instead, due to the [[amphiphile|amphiphilic]] nature of the FSL, the construct will spontaneously form into a bilayer. The surface of the bilayer will be hydrophilic, allowing it to interact and anchor the FSLs to the hydrophilic surface. }}
=== Amphiphilic FSL Kode construct ===
The FSL Kode construct by nature of its composition in possessing both hydrophobic and hydrophilic regions are [[amphiphile|amphiphilic]] (or amphipathic). This characteristic determines the way in which the construct will interact with surfaces. When present in a [[solution]] they may form simple [[micelles]] or adopt more complex bilayer structures with two simplistic examples shown in ''Fig. 5a''. More complex structures are expected. The actual nature of FSL micelles has not been determined. However, based on normal structural function of micelles, it is expected that it will be determined in part by the combination of functional group, spacer and lipid together with temperature, [[concentration]], size and [[hydrophobicity|hydrophobicity/hydrophilicity]] for each FSL Kode construct type.
Surface coatings will occur via two theoretical mechanisms, the first being direct hydrophobic interaction of the lipid tail with a hydrophobic surface resulting in a [[monolayer]] of FSL at the surface ''(Fig. 5b)''. Hydrophobic binding of the FSL will be via its hydrophobic lipid tail interacting directly with the hydrophobic ([[lipophilic]]) surface. The second surface coating will be through the formation of bilayers as the lipid tail is unable to react with the hydrophilic surface. In this case the lipids will induce the formation of a bilayer, the surface of which will be hydrophilic. This hydrophilic membrane will then interact directly with the hydrophilic surface and will probably encapsulate [[fibres]]. This hydrophilic bilayer binding is the expected mechanism by which FSLs are able to bind to fibrous membranes such as paper<ref name="Henry2012c"/> and glass fibres ''(Fig. 5c)'' and ''(Fig. 9)''.
=== Lipid membrane modification ===
{{multiple image <!-- Essential parameters --> | align = right | direction = horizontal | width = 300
<!-- Image 1 --> | image1 = Koded biomembrane.svg | width1 = | alt1 = | caption1 = ''Fig. 6a'' A [[cell membrane|plasma membrane]] modified with FSL constructs (by analogy to sunflower), creating a [[kodecyte]] membrane.
<!-- Image 2 --> | image2 = FSLs inserted into a liposome.svg | width2 = | alt2 = | caption2 = ''Fig. 6b'' FSL constructs (by analogy to sunflower) inserted via their lipid tail (roots) into a [[liposome]]. The spacer of the FSL (stalk) hold the functional group of the FSL (flower head) away from the surface. }}
After labeling of the surface with the selected F bioactive(s) the constructs will be present and orientated at the membrane surface. It is expected that the FSL will be highly mobile within the membrane and the choice of lipid tail will effect is relative partitioning within the membrane.<ref name="Korchagina2012" /><ref name="Harrison2010" /> The construct unless it has [[Lipid bilayer phase behavior|flip-flop behavior]] is expected to remain surface presented. However, the modification is not permanent in living cells and constructs will be lost (consumed) at a rate proportional to the activity at the membrane and [[Cell division|division rate of the cell]] (with dead cells remaining highly labeled).<ref name="Blake2011" /> Additionally, when present ''in vivo'' with serum lipids FSLs will elute from the membrane into the plasma at a rate of about 1% per hour.<ref name="Hadac2011" /><ref name="Oliver2011b" /> In fixed cells or inactive cells (e.g. red cells) stored in serum free media the constructs are retained normally.<ref name="Blake2011" />
Liposomes are easy koded by simply adding FSL Kode constructs into the preparation. Contacting koded liposomes with microplates or other surfaces can cause the labeling of the microplate surface.
=== Non-biologic surface interaction === Non-biologic surface coatings will occur via two mechanisms, the first being direct hydrophobic interaction of the lipid tail with a hydrophobic surface resulting in a monolayer of FSL at the surface. The second surface coating will be through the formation of bilayers, which probably either encapsulate fibres or being via the hydrophilic F group. This is the expected mechanism by which FSLs bind to fibrous membranes such as paper<ref name="Henry2012c" /> and glass fibres. A recent study has found that when FSL Kode constructs are optimised, could in a few seconds glycosylate almost any non-biological surface including metals, glass, plastics, rubbers, and other polymers.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Ultra-Fast Glyco-Coating of Non-Biological Surfaces|url = http://www.mdpi.com/1422-0067/17/1/118|journal = International Journal of Molecular Sciences|date = 2016-01-16|pages = 118|volume = 17|issue = 1|doi = 10.3390/ijms17010118|language = en|first = Eleanor|last = Williams|first2 = Katie|last2 = Barr|first3 = Elena|last3 = Korchagina|first4 = Alexander|last4 = Tuzikov|first5 = Stephen|last5 = Henry|first6 = Nicolai|last6 = Bovin}}</ref>
== Technology features ==
The technological features of FSL Kode constructs and the koding process can be summarized as follows: * '''Rapid and simple''' – simple contact for 10–120 minutes and constructs spontaneously and stably incorporate – no washing required.<ref name="Blake2011" /> * '''Replicable''' – same variables (time, temperature, concentration) equals the same result.<ref name="Blake2011" /><ref name="Frame2007" /> * '''Toxicity''' – FSL constructs are [[biocompatible]], disperse into biological solutions without [[solvents]], detergents. They label non-covalently and are non-genetic. Normal [[vitality]] and functionality is maintained in modified cells/virions/organisms.<ref name="Harrison2010" /><ref name="Oliver2011a" /><ref name="Oliver2011b" /><ref name="Lan2012" /> Toxicity/vitality experiments in small laboratory animals, [[zebrafish]], [[cell culture]]s, [[spermatozoa]] and [[embryos]] find no [[toxic]] effects within physiological ranges. * '''Amphiphilic''' – the [[amphiphilic]] nature of the FSL Kode construct makes them water dispersible (clear solution of micelles), yet once interacted with a membrane they insert/coat and become water resistant * '''Variable design''' – a single F can be presented in more than 100 ways by varying the spacer and lipid. * '''High biovisibility''' – as the spacer holds the F moiety away for the membrane it is able to achieve increased sensitivity, specificity and reactivity can be optimized by use of multiple and variable biomarker presentations on the same surface. * '''Additive''' – FSL modification is compatible with other technologies allowing users to add additional features to cells/viruses/organisms/surfaces already modified by more traditional methods. Multiple FSL constructs may be added to a surface simultaneously by simply creating a mix of FSL Kode constructs. Constructs insert into living or fixed cell ([[Glutaraldehyde#Fixative|glutaraldehyde]]) membranes. [[File:RFG maleimide construction.svg|thumb|''Fig. 8'' FSLs can be easily created from [[cysteine]]-containing peptides, proteins or any other [[thiol]]s of biological interest. The mixing of a cysteine containing peptide with FSL-RFG(Maleimide), in [[N-Methylmorpholine|4MMF]] buffer, allows the peptide to react with the [[maleimide]] residue of the FSL (through the well-known [[Michael reaction|Michael nucleophilic addition reaction]]). Following overnight incubation then vacuum drying, an FSL peptide is created. No purification is required.|400x400px]] * '''Simple FSL peptide synthesis''' – there is a reactive-functional-group FSL Kode construct with maleimide as its functional group which can be used for preparation of FSLs from [[cysteine]]-containing peptides, proteins or any other [[thiol]]s of biological interest.<ref name="Henry2011" /><ref name="Henry2012a" /> The effective synthetic approach is based on the well-known [[Michael reaction|Michael nucleophilic]] addition to maleimides ''(Fig. 7)''. * '''Synthetic "Gylcolipids"''' – one family of the FSL constructs are synthetic [[glycolipid]]s with well-defined hydrophobic tails and carbohydrate head groups
=== Koded membranes surfaces and solutions === FSL constructs have a wide range of uses and they have been used to modify the following: * '''Cells''' – [[blood cell]]s,<ref name="Blake2011" /><ref name="Korchagina2012" /><ref name="Henry2009" /><ref name="Frame2007" /><ref name="Georgakopoulos2011" /><ref name="Oliver2011a" /><ref name="Oliver2011b" /><ref name="Hult2012" /><ref name="Henry2012b" /><ref name="Heathcote2010" /><ref name="Nadarajan2011" /><ref name="Henry2011" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name="Henry2012c" /><ref name="Chesla2010" /> [[Cell culture|culture lines]],<ref name="Blake2011" /> [[embryos]],<ref name="Blake2011" /> [[spermatozoa]]<ref name="Blake2011" /> * '''Viruses'''<ref name="Hadac2011" /> – influenza,<ref name="Korchagina2012" /> [[measles]], [[varicella]] * '''Organisms''' – [[parasite]]s, [[microbe]]s, [[zebrafish]]<ref name="Lan2012" /> * '''Liposomes''' – also micelles, lipid particles<ref name="Oliver2011a" /> * '''Surfaces/fibres''' – hydrophobic or hydrophilic membranes/fibres, paper,<ref name="Henry2012c" /> [[nitrocellulose]], cotton, silk, glass, [[Teflon]], [[silica]], magnetic beads (microspheres)<ref>{{Cite web|title = Rapid biofunctionalization of magnetic beads with function-spacer-lipid constructs|url = http://sepmag.eu/blog/bid/401297/Rapid-biofunctionalization-of-magnetic-beads-with-function-spacer-lipid-constructs|website = sepmag.eu|accessdate = 2015-12-01}}</ref> etc. * '''Solutions''' – saline, plasma/serum, culture media
== Methodology for FSL use (koding) == [[File:Preparation of kodecytes and kodevirions.svg|thumb|''Fig. 9'' Preparation of [[kodecytes]]/[[kodevirions]]. Simply mix cells/virions with an FSL solution (containing 1 or more FSLs) and incubate for 10–120 minutes at 37°C (or at temperatures as low as 4°C). The constructs will spontaneously incorporate into the membrane and no further steps are required.|400x400px]] FSL constructs, when in solution ([[Saline (medicine)|saline]]) and in contact, will spontaneously incorporate into cell and virus membranes.<ref name="Blake2011" /> The methodology involves simply preparing a solution of FSL construct(s) in the range of 1–1000 [[µg]]/[[millilitre|mL]]. The actual concentration will depend on the construct and the quantity of construct required in the membrane. One part of FSL solution is added to one part of cells (up to 100% [[suspension (chemistry)|suspension]]) and they are incubated at a set temperature within the range of 4–37 °C (39–99 °F) depending on temperature compatibility of the cells being modified. The higher the temperature, the faster the rate of FSL insertion into the membrane. For red blood cells, at 37 °C incubation for 2 hours achieves >95% insertion with at least 50% insertion being achieved within 20 minutes. In general, FSL insertion time of 4 hours at room temperature or 20 hours at 4 °C gives results similar to 1 hour at 37 °C for carbohydrate based FSLs inserting into red blood cells.<ref name="Blake2011" /> The resultant kodecytes or kodevirions do not required to be washed, however this option should be considered if an excess of FSL construct is used in the koding process.
== Applications == FSL Kode constructs have been used for research and development, [[diagnostic]] products, and are currently being investigated as potential [[therapeutic]] agents.
=== Kodecytes === {{main article|Kodecyte#Applications}}
FSL have been used to create human red cell kodecytes that have been used to detect and identify blood group allo-antibodies<ref name="Heathcote2010" /><ref name="Nadarajan2011" /><ref name="Henry2011" /> as [[ABO blood group system|ABO]] sub-group mimics,<ref name="Hult2012" /> ABO quality control systems,<ref name="Henry2009" /> [[serologic]] teaching kits<ref name="Henry2012b" /> and a [[syphilis]] diagnostic.<ref name="Chesla2010" /> Kodecytes have also demonstrated that FSL-FLRO4 is a suitable reagent for labelling [[packed red blood cells]] (PRBC) at any point during routine storage and look to facilitate the development of immunoassays and transfusion models focused on addressing the mechanisms involved in [[Transfusion-related immunomodulation|tansfusion-related immunomodulation]] (TRIM).<ref name=":1" /> Murine kodecytes have been experimentally used to determine ''in vivo'' cell survival,<ref name="Oliver2011b" /> and create model [[Transfusion reaction#Complications of transfusions|transfusion reactions]].<ref name="Oliver2011a" /><ref name="Oliver2011b" /> Zebrafish kodecytes have been used to determine real time ''in vivo'' cell migration.<ref name="Lan2012" /> Kodecytes have been used to create influenza diagnostics.<ref name="Korchagina2012" /> Kodecytes which have been modified with FSL-GB3 were unable to be infected with the [[HIV virus]].<ref name="Harrison2010" /><ref name="Branch2008" />
=== Kodevirions === {{main article|Kodevirions#Applications}}
Kodevirions are FSL modified viruses. Several FSL Kode constructs have been used to label viruses to assist in their [[Flow cytometry|flow-cytometric visualisation]]<ref name="Hadac2011" /> and to track them real time distribution in animal models.<ref name="Hadac2011" /> They have also been used to modify the surface of viruses with the intention of targeting them to be used to attach [[tumor]]s ([[oncolytic]]).<ref name="Hadac2011" />
=== Kodesomes === Kodesomes are liposomes that have been decorated with FSL Kode constructs. These have been used to deposit FSL constructs onto microplates to create diagnostic [[assay]]s. They also have the potential for therapeutic use.<ref name="Harrison2011" />
=== Koded solutions === These are solutions containing FSL Kode constructs where the construct will exist as a clear micellular dispersion. FSL-GB3 as a solution/gel has been used to inhibit HIV infection<ref name="Harrison2010" /> and to neutralise [[Shiga toxin]].<ref name="Harrison2010" /> FSL blood group A as a solution has been used to neutralise circulating antibodies in a [[mouse]] model and allow incompatible blood group A ([[murine]] kodecytes) transfusion.<ref name="Oliver2011a" /> This model experiment was used to demonstrate the potential of FSLs to neutralise circulating antibody and allow for incompatible blood transfusion or [[organ transplantation]].<ref name="Henry2012c" />
=== Koded surfaces === [[File:Inkjet Printed FSLs.jpg|thumb|''Fig. 10'' FSL constructs can be printed with a [[Inkjet printer|standard desktop inkjet printer]] directly onto paper to create [[immunoassay]]s. Image is a typical example of an inkjet printed enzyme immunoassay (EIA) where 12 different FSL constructs were printed as identifying codes on paper and then reacted against different samples. The antibody activity in the samples can be identified by appearance of words identifying the target antigen. An empty inkjet cartridge is filled with an FSL construct and words, barcodes, or graphics are printed. A [[Poly(methyl methacrylate)|Perspex]] template is adhered to the surface to create [[Microtiter plate|reaction wells]]. The method is then a standard [[immunoassay|EIA]] procedure, but blocking of serum is not required and undiluted serum can be used. A typical EIA procedure is as follows: add serum, incubate, wash by immersion, add secondary EIA [[Immunoassay#Detection Antibody|detection antibody]], incubate, wash, add [[Nitro blue tetrazolium chloride|NBT]]/BCIP precipitating substrate and stop the reaction when developed by washing. The end result is stable for years.|541x541px]]
All FSL Kode constructs disperse in water and are therefore compatible with [[inkjet printer]]s. FSL constructs can be printed with a standard desktop inkjet printer directly onto paper to create immunoassays.<ref name="Henry2012c" /> An empty ink cartridge is filled with an FSL construct and words, [[barcode]]s, or graphics are printed. A [[Perspex]] template is adhered to the surface to create reaction wells. The method is then a standard [[Immunoassay|EIA]] procedure, but blocking of serum is not required and undiluted serum can be used. A typical procedure is as follows: add serum, incubate, wash by immersion, add secondary EIA conjugate, incubate, wash, add [[Nitro blue tetrazolium chloride|NBT]]/[[BCIP]] precipitating substrate and stop the reaction when developed by washing ''(Fig. 9)''. The end result is stable for years.
