Trans-Golgi network vesicle protein 23 A ('''TVP23A''') is a [[protein]] coded for the TVP23A [[gene]], formally known as FAM18A.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gene/780776 |title=TVP23A}}</ref> TVP23A is located on chromosome 16.<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=https://www.genecards.org/cgi-bin/carddisp.pl?gene=TVP23A|website=GeneCards|title=GeneCards}}</ref> It is known to have human paralogs, [[FAM18B1|TVP23B]] and TVP23C, as well as orthologs in many different species, notably yeast, mice, and chickens.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ieb/research/acembly/av.cgi?db=human&c=Gene&l=FAM18A|website=AceView|title=AceView}}</ref> The general consensus on the TVP23A protein indicate that it has some function in the late [[Golgi apparatus]] and is involved in retrograde transport from endosomes back into the Golgi apparatus. The nature of this transport is still unknown.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genatlas.medecine.univ-paris5.fr/fiche.php?n=28506|website=GenAtlas|title=GenAtlas}}</ref>
== Gene ==
=== Locus === TVP23A is located at cytogenic band 16p13.13, on the negative strand of [[Chromosome 16 (human)|Chromosome 16]].<ref name=":1" /> [[File:TVP23A Location.png|Location of TVP23A on Chromosome 16 (red line)|none|frame]]
===Alternative Names=== TVP23A stands for '''<u>T</u>'''rans-Golgi network '''<u>V</u>'''esicle '''<u>P</u>'''rotein '''<u>23A</u>''' TVP23A, is the current name for the protein. Aliases of TVP23A include FAM18A, and rarely YDR084C.<ref name=":0" />
== mRNA ==
=== Isoforms === There are two known [[isoform]]s of TVP23A, variant one and variant two, with variant one being the more common variant in humans.<ref name=":1" />
== Protein ==
=== Structure ===
TVP23A is a member of the pfam superfamily containing the [[domain of unknown function]] 846 (DUF846).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Structure/cdd/cddsrv.cgi?uid=191380 |title=DUF846}}</ref> TVP23A has a predicted molecular weight of 24.1 kilodaltons, an isoelectric point of 6.5, and relatively high amounts of [[tryptophan]] and [[phenylalanine]].<ref name="Biology Workbench">{{cite web|title=SAPS|url=http://seqtool.sdsc.edu/CGI/BW.cgi#!|website=Biology Workbench|publisher=SDSC}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> The secondary structure of TVP23A consists primarily of [[alpha helices]] composing 4 transmembrane domains.<ref>{{cite web|title=TMHMM|url=http://seqtool.sdsc.edu/CGI/BW.cgi#!|website=Biology Workbench}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> There is not much information on the tertiary structure of TVP23A or its homologs. iTASSER<ref>{{cite web|title=I-TASSER server for protein structure and function prediction|url=http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/I-TASSER/|website=zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu}}</ref> was used to generate a prediction for the folding pattern of TVP23A, which supports the presence of multiple helix structures. [[File:TVP23Astructure.jpg|none|thumb|Protein structure of TVP23A as predicted by iTASSER]]
== Expression == TVP23A is ubiquitously expressed in all human tissues.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gene: TVP23A|url=http://www.ensembl.org/Homo_sapiens/Gene/ExpressionAtlas?g=ENSG00000166676;r=16:10760919-10818794|website=www.ensembl.org|language=en-gb}}</ref> There is evidence of higher expression in the brain tissue of mice.<ref>{{cite web|title=GDS3142 / 1435130_at|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/tools/profileGraph.cgi?ID=GDS3142:1435130_at|website=www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov}}</ref> The promoter for TVP23A is GXP_91266, spanning 1403 base pairs located on the negative strand of chromosome 16.<ref>{{cite web|title=ElDorado|url=https://www.genomatix.de/|website=Genomatix.de}}</ref>
== Function == The hypothesized function of TVP23A is a transmembrane protein involved in retrograde transport of [[Vesicle (biology and chemistry)|vesicles]] from early [[endosome]]s into the late Golgi apparatus.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Inadome|first1=Hironori|last2=Noda|first2=Yoichi|last3=Kamimura|first3=Yurika|last4=Adachi|first4=Hiroyuki|last5=Yoda|first5=Koji|title=Tvp38, Tvp23, Tvp18 and Tvp15: Novel membrane proteins in the Tlg2-containing Golgi/endosome compartments of Saccharomyces cerevisiae|journal=Experimental Cell Research|date=February 2007|volume=313|issue=4|pages=688–697|doi=10.1016/j.yexcr.2006.11.008|pmid=17178117}}</ref> TVP23A interactions with [[SNARE (protein)|SNARE]] TVI1 were found to be required for retrograde transport. <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Stein|first1=Ivar S.|last2=Gottfried|first2=Anna|last3=Zimmermann|first3=Jana|last4=Fischer von Mollard|first4=Gabriele|title=interacts genetically with the yeast SNARE and functions in retrograde transport from the early endosome to the late Golgi|journal=Biochemical Journal|date=1 April 2009|volume=419|issue=1|pages=229–236|doi=10.1042/BJ20081973|pmid=19076069}}</ref>
== Interacting Proteins == TVP23A has been found to interact with four different proteins via Yeast [[Two-hybrid screening|two hybrid arrays]].<ref>{{cite web|title=IntAct|url=http://www.ebi.ac.uk/intact/|website=www.ebi.ac.uk|language=en}}</ref> Two of these proteins, YIPF1 and YIPF2, are believed to be Golgi transport proteins. {| class="wikitable" |'''Protein''' |'''Experiment''' |'''Function''' |- |[[SCAND1]] |Two hybrid array |Potentially a transcription factor (SCAN domains common in ZFP) |- |[[WIPF2]] |Two hybrid array |Believed to be involved in actin filament remodeling |- |[[YIPF1]] |Two hybrid array |Golgi transport protein |- |YIPF2 |Two hybrid array |Golgi transport protein |}
== Homology ==
=== Homologous Domains === TVP23A is a DUF846 containing protein, which is homologous throughout TVP-type proteins. This domain contains the 4 transmembrane domains of TVP23A<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pfam.xfam.org/family/PF05832|title=Pfam: Family: DUF846 (PF05832)|website=pfam.xfam.org}}</ref>
=== Paralogs === TVP23A has two paralogs, [[FAM18B1|TVP23B]] and TVP23C. TVP23B and TVP23C are 96% similar to each other, and both are located on [[Chromosome 17 (human)|chromosome 17]].<ref>{{cite web|title=BLAST: Basic Local Alignment Search Tool|url=https://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi|website=blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov}}</ref> Due to the locations of these three genes, and their identities to each other, it is probable that ancestral TVP23 underwent [[Gene duplication|duplication]] and [[Translocation (genetics)|translocation]], giving rise to TVP23A on chromosome 16 and TVP23B/C on chromosome 17, which then underwent a second duplication to form TVP23B and TVP23C. {| class="wikitable" !Gene !Seq Length !Seq Identity !Chromosome |- |TVP23A |213 |100% |16 |- |TVP23B |205 |54% |17 |- |TVP23C |203 |53% |17 |}
=== Orthologs === TVP23A has been found in all multicellular eukaryotes, including fungi. This gene has not been found in bacteria.<ref>{{cite web|title=UCSC Genome Browser Home|url=https://genome.ucsc.edu/|website=genome.ucsc.edu}}</ref>

'''USS ''Albany''''', the first [[United States Navy]] ship of that name,<ref name=DANFS/> was built in the 1840s for the US Navy. The ship was among the last of the wooden sloops powered by sail and saw extensive service in the [[Mexican–American War|Mexican War]]. Before and after her combat service, ''Albany'' conducted surveillance and observation missions throughout the Caribbean. In September 1854, during a journey along the coast of [[Venezuela]], ''Albany'' was lost with all hands on 28 or 29 September 1854. Included among the 250 men lost were several sons and grandsons of politically prominent men.
==Description and construction== ''Albany'' was one of a group of eight [[Full-rigged ship|full-rigged]], three-[[mast (sailing)|masted]] wooden [[sloop]]s built in the early 1840s that were the last American sailing sloops to be commissioned.<ref name=Potter>E. B. Potter,''Sea Power: A Naval History.'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=kWA9BAAAQBAJ&pg=PT157 Chapter 11: Navies in Transition (Administrative Changes)]. Naval Institute Press, Jun 15, 2014. 9781612517674</ref> The ship measured {{convert|147|ft|11|in|m|1}} long [[Length between perpendiculars|between perpendiculars]] and she had a [[Beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|38|ft|6|in|m|1}}. ''Albany'' had a draft of {{convert|17|ft|9|in|m|1}} and had a tonnage of 1042 [[tons burthen]]. The ship had a crew of 210 officers and enlisted men.<ref name=s2>Paul H. Silverstone. ''The Sailing Navy 1775–1854'' Routledge, 2006, 0415978726 p. 42</ref> She could maintain a speed of {{convert|13|kn|lk=in}}.<ref name=Albassoc>''USS Albany Association''. [http://www.ussalbany.org/chart.htm Ship's Characteristics] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304054623/http://www.ussalbany.org/chart.htm |date=4 March 2016 }}. 10/06/2014. Accessed 5 November 2015.</ref> ''Albany'' could mount up to four {{convert|8|in|mm|0|adj=on}} shell guns and eighteen {{convert|32|pdr|kg|lk=on|adj=on}} cannon. By 1853, she was armed with six 8-inch guns and sixteen 32-pounder cannon.<ref name=s2/>
The ship's [[keel]] was [[laid down]] in 1843 at the [[New York Navy Yard]]; she was [[Ceremonial ship launching|launched]] on 27 June 1846, and [[Ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 6 November, with [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] [[Samuel Livingston Breese]] in command.<ref name=DANFS/> Her construction was accelerated so she would be complete for the impending [[Mexican–American War|war]] with Mexico. Although she could carry 22 guns, ''Albany'' sailed with only 20.<ref name=b21>Thomas Berner, ''The Brooklyn Navy Yard'', Arcadia, 1999, 9780738556956, pp. 21, 127</ref>
==Service history in war with Mexico== The sloop put to sea for her first cruise on 26 November 1846 and joined the [[Home Squadron]]—then engaged in operations against Mexican forces—on 8 January 1847 at [[Anton Lizardo]]. Soon thereafter, however, she left the Mexican coast for an independent cruise to the vicinity of the [[Azores]]. Upon her return to the east coast of Mexico early in March, ''Albany'' guarded the transport anchorage at [[Isla Verde, Puerto Rico|Isla Verde]] in preparation for [[General (United States)|General]] [[Winfield Scott]]'s operations against [[Veracruz, Veracruz|Veracruz]]. During the 9 March amphibious action, ''Albany'' landed the reserve elements under Brigadier General [[David E. Twiggs]]. Because the Mexican leaders chose not to oppose the landings, ''Albany'' saw no combat. Later, on 22 March, the sloop of war sent one of her eight-inch shell guns and its crew ashore to assist in the [[siege of Veracruz]].<ref name=DANFS>''Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships,'' [http://www.history.navy.mil/research/histories/ship-histories/danfs/a/albany-i.html USS Albany (1)], Published:Fri Jun 12 06:40:54 EDT 2015. Accessed 3 November 2015</ref>
After Veracruz surrendered on 29 March, ''Albany'' moved to the next objective—[[Alvarado, Veracruz|Alvarado]]. The Mexican forces, however, had already abandoned that port; and [[Lieutenant]] [[Charles G. Hunter]], commanding {{USS|Scourge|1846|2}}, which arrived first, took possession of the town. ''Albany'' soon headed for another target—[[Tuxpan]]. She and the other ships of the squadron arrived at the mouth of the [[Tuxpan River (Veracruz)|Tuxpan River]] on the morning of 17 April. Capt. Breese—commanding ''Albany''—then formed his landing party of over 1,500 sailors and marines drawn from all ships in the squadron. They embarked in the barges and the six ships chosen to ascend the river and [[Battle of Tuxpan|capture Tuxpan]]. Although ''Albany'' herself did not participate in the action, Breese and his landing party did. From 18–22 April, Breese's force moved up the river, engaged and captured two artillery batteries, destroyed fortifications and military equipment at Tuxpan, and then retired down the river to rejoin the squadron. When the American warships dispersed to various blockade stations along the eastern coast of Mexico, ''Albany'' and {{USS|Reefer|1846|2}} remained off the mouth of the Tuxpan River.<ref name=DANFS/>
During service on the blockade at various other points, ''Albany'' arrived off the mouth of the [[Tabasco River]] by 13 June. As in the Tuxpan operation, members of her crew joined an inland expedition. The movement upriver began late in the first [[dog watch]] on 14 June. In two days, the American force ascended the river, disembarked the landing force, routed the defenders on the approaches to [[Tabasco]], and [[Second Battle of Tabasco|captured the town]]. The Americans remained there until 22 July, when [[yellow fever]] and Mexican troops forced the evacuation of the town.<ref name= DANFS/>
Subsequently, ''Albany'' headed home for repairs. She left the Mexican coast on 11 July and arrived in [[Hampton Roads, Virginia]], on 6 August. From there, she soon moved north to [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]] where she completed her repairs on 27 September. On 10 October, the sloop of war put to sea to return to the [[Gulf of Mexico]]; she resumed blockade duty along the Mexican coast until March 1848, when she was sent to [[Venezuela]] to protect American citizens there during a highly volatile [[constitutional crisis]].<ref name=DANFS/>
===Midshipman controversy===
With the Mexican–American War at an end, ''Albany'' began cruising the Caribbean-West Indies region. That duty lasted until 12 September 1848, when she returned to Norfolk.<ref name=DANFS/> During the West Indies cruise, however, [[John McIntosh Kell]] and three other passed [[midshipmen]] refused a direct order they considered demeaning: they had been ordered to light a candle to summon the relief attendant, a task generally assigned to a midshipman, not a ''passed'' midshipman. The commander, Victor M. Randolph, brought them up on charges, of which they were convicted and released from the Navy in November 1849, although all were reinstated a year later.<ref>The Civil War Naval Encyclopedia, Volume 1, ''John McIntosh Kell,'' ABC-CLIO, 2011 9781598843385, p. 336</ref>
==Post-war cruises==
Between 15 November 1848 and the latter part of 1853, the sloop made three more extended deployments in the Caribbean-West Indies area as a unit of the Home Squadron. On 12 December 1853, ''Albany'' set sail from Boston, Massachusetts. In May 1854, the commander had filed a report with the [[Secretary of the Navy]] [[James C. Dobbin]] that the [[main mast]] of ''Albany'' was unseaworthy.<ref name=Haase666>Adelaide Rosalie Haasse, ''Index to United States documents relating to foreign affairs, 1828–1861, Volume 1,'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=918bAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA666 Main Mast Unseaworthy]. Carnegie Institution of Washington, 1914.</ref> On 20 May, Victor Randolph, the former commander of ''Albany'' and now commanding officer (''[[pro tem]]'') of the [[Naval Air Station Pensacola|Naval Yard Warrington]], reported that an appropriate mast had been identified and was ready for ''Albany''. During the replacement of the main mast, there was also some discussion of the condition of the [[Mast (sailing)|fore mast]]. Apparently both were replaced.<ref name=Haasse21>Haasse, p. 21.</ref>
===Last cruise=== Initially, Gerry had instructions to sail to San Juan, [[Cartagena, Colombia|Cartagena]], and Aspinwall (now [[Colón, Panama]]), and ''Albany'' set out on 29 June. By 11 August, instructions ordered Gerry to pass along the coast and to investigate a suspicious ship lurking near [[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands|Saint Thomas]]. Additional instructions, sent separately, told Gerry to continue patrolling the [[Windward Islands]] and [[Grand Turk Island|Grand Turk]].<ref name=Haasse21/>
Inline with its instructions, ''Albany'' arrived in [[Curacao]] on 7 September 1854, from [[La Guaira]], [[Venezuela]]. She stayed in port for two days, and left on the morning of the 9th for [[Cartagena, Colombia|Cartagena]] in Colombia, in what was then called [[Republic of New Granada|New Granada]]. A letter from a Curacao correspondent of 19 September 1854 reported that all the crew were well. The sloop made an imposing appearance moored in the harbor and, upon leaving port, she saluted one of the forts with twenty-one guns, which was answered, and then saluted a Dutch ship, the [[corvette]] ''Palloo'' with eleven guns.<ref name=Veritas>Veritas. "The Dutch West Indies." <u>Weekly Herald</u> [New York, New York] [Oct. 21, 1854]: 335. 19th Century U.S. Newspapers. Web. 3 Nov. 2015. {{subscription}}</ref> On 28 September, Commander Gerry sent a report updating his superiors on the cruise, dispatched from Aspinwall.<ref name=Haase666/> ''Albany'' departed Aspinwall, [[Colombia]] on 28–29 September 1854, intending to sail to New York. She was never seen again.<ref name= DANFS/>
By the November, reports circulated through coastal cities that there was much "uneasiness felt in Washington in relation to the sloop-of-war ''Albany''," which had not been heard from since 28 September, when she left Aspinwall for New York.<ref>"Multiple News Items." <u>Bangor Daily Whig & Courier</u> [Bangor, Maine] 13 Nov. 1854: n.p. 19th Century U.S. Newspapers. Web. 3 Nov. 2015.</ref> By early December, the steamer [[USS Princeton (1851)|USS ''Princeton'']] had returned from searching for the missing sloop, which had not been seen or heard from on any of the channels frequented by ship traffic of the [[British West Indies]].<ref name=Herald><u>The Weekly Herald</u> (New York, New York), Saturday, December 09, 1854; Issue 49.</ref> In late December, a report surfaced that the vessel had arrived at Cartagena safely,<ref><u>Boston Investigator</u> (Boston, Massachusetts), Wednesday, December 20, 1854; Issue 34.</ref> but this report was apparently in error, possibly generated by the arrival of the report that Gerry had mailed before leaving Aspinwall at the end of September.<ref name=Haasse21>Haasse, p. 21.</ref> By this time, the Navy's steam ships were searching the area for ''Albany''.<ref><u>The Boston Daily Atlas</u> (Boston, Massachusetts), Saturday, March 03, 1855; Issue 208. <u>Daily National Intelligencer</u> (Washington, District Of Columbia), Monday, March 05, 1855; Issue 13,109.</ref> The steamer [[USS Fulton (1837)|USS ''Fulton'']] searched from January to May from Cartegena to Aspinwall, the [[Bay of Darien]], into the [[Gulf of Honduras|Bay of Guatemala]], and along the [[Mosquito Coast]].<ref>Haasse, p. 558.</ref> By January 1856, after an exhaustive search of 15 months, the ship was given up as lost.<ref><u>[[The Daily Cleveland Herald]]</u> (Cleveland, Ohio), Tuesday, January 08, 1856; Issue 6.</ref>
===Family compensation=== The Department of the Navy requested an inquiry into the loss, which was passed on to the appropriate Senate Committee.<ref>Franklin Pierce, Correspondence with the Senate, ''To the Senate (re sloop-of-war Albany),'' 26 February 1855, Congressional Edition, Volume 745, [https://books.google.com/books?id=mWZHAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA331 p. 331].</ref> A second craft, {{USS|Porpoise|1836|6}}, had been lost in a [[typhoon]] while conducting an exploratory cruise of the [[Bonins]], the [[Wanshan Archipelago|Ladrones]], and the [[Mariana Islands|Mariana]] islands.<ref>''Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships,'' [http://www.history.navy.mil/research/histories/ship-histories/danfs/p/porpoise-ii.html ''USS Porpoise (1836)''], Mon Aug 24 09:47:26 EDT 2015, Accessed 4 November 2015.</ref> By resolution of the Senate, a fund was provided for the widows and orphans of the officers, mariners, and seamen of both ships. Furthermore, the appropriate wages were paid to the families (including parents, brothers, or sisters) of the men lost, despite the loss of Nixon White (Purser)'s account books.<ref>United States. Congress, John Cook Rives (ed), United States. Blair and Rives, 1856, p. 809.</ref> In the case of Rowland Leach, the ship's carpenter, this amounted to $1559, including $779 for a year's gratuitous pay ordered by the Department of the Navy.<ref>See Probate Records, Rowland Leach (August 1855). [http://search.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/sse.dll?indiv=1&dbid=9069&h=2261726&ssrc=pt&tid=85114865&pid=48587271751&usePUB=true Probate Records 1648–1924 page 5.] (Middlesex County, Massachusetts); Author: Massachusetts. Probate Court (Middlesex County); Probate Place: Middlesex, Massachusetts.</ref> [[Image:Stuart Portrait-Of-Captain-James-T.-Gerry.jpg|thumb|James Thompson Gerry, last commander of USS ''Albany'']]
===Partial list of the lost===
As of 30 June 1854, the crew of ''Albany'' consisted of 18 officers, 156 seaman, and 23 Marines. It is likely the ship's complement was little changed when she was lost three months later.<ref name=Herald/> The crew included several sons and grandsons of prominent men: Commander James T. Gerry, youngest son of [[Elbridge Gerry]], formerly [[Vice President of the United States]], Lieutenant John Quincy Adams, grandson of the [[John Adams|second president]] and nephew of the [[John Quincy Adams|sixth]], and Midshipman Bennet Israel Riley, son of [[Brevet (military)|Brevet]] General [[Bennet C. Riley]], the former military governor of California during its statehood [[History of California#California statehood (1850)|controversy]].<ref name=NCR>''Navy Casualty Reports, 1776–1941'', Lost and Wrecked Ships, Explosions and Steam Casualties, [https://www.fold3.com/image/?rec=268738888&terms=Bennet%20Riley p. 5], Fold3 12-003. Accessed 3 November 2015. {{Subscription}}</ref>

[http://www.ussalbany.org/List%20of%20Commanding%20Officers.htm ''Commanding Officers''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304071001/http://www.ussalbany.org/List%20of%20Commanding%20Officers.htm |date=4 March 2016 }}. 1999. Accessed 5 November 2015.</ref> *John Kelly, 1847–48<ref name=Albassoccommanders/> *Victor M. Randolf, 1848–50<ref name=Albassoccommanders/> *Charles T. '''Voltinism''' is a term used in biology to indicate the number of broods or generations of an organism in a year. The term is most often applied to insects, and is particularly in use in [[sericulture]], where [[silkworm]] varieties vary in their voltinism.
* '''Univoltine''' – (adjective) referring to organisms having one brood or generation per year * '''Bivoltine''' – (adjective) referring to organisms having two broods or generations per year * '''Multivoltine''' – (adjective) referring to organisms having more than two broods or generations per year * '''Semivoltine''' – (adjective) referring to organisms whose [[generation time]] is more than one year
==Examples== The [[speckled wood butterfly]] is '''univoltine''' in the northern part of its range, e.g. northern Scandinavia. Adults emerge in late spring, mate, and die shortly after laying eggs; their offspring will grow until [[pupation]], enter [[diapause]] in anticipation of the winter, and emerge as adults the following year – thus resulting in a single generation of butterflies per year. In southern Scandinavia, the same species is '''bivoltine'''<ref name="Aalberg" /> – here, the offspring of spring-emerging adults will develop directly into adults during the summer, mate, and die. Their offspring in turn constitute a second generation, which is the generation that will enter winter diapause and emerge as adults (and mate) in the spring of the following year. This results in a pattern of one short-lived generation (c. 2–3 months) that breeds during the summer, and one long-lived generation (ca. 9-10 months) that diapauses through the winter and breeds in the spring. The [[Parnassius smintheus|Rocky Mountain parnassian]] and the [[High brown fritillary]] are more examples of univoltine butterfly species.<ref name="Aalberg">Aalberg Haugen IM, Berger D, and Gotthard K. 2012. The evolution of alternative developmental pathways: footprints of selection on life-history traits in a butterfly. 12pp. Journal of Evolutionary Biology, 25:7, Available online: [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1420-9101.2012.02525.x/full]</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Shepard|first1=Jon|last2=Guppy|first2=Crispin|title=Butterflies of British Columbia: Including Western Alberta, Southern Yukon, the Alaska Panhandle, Washington, Northern Oregon, Northern Idaho, and Northwestern Montana|date=2011|publisher=UBC Press|isbn=9780774844376|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=il6rJ7glHNQC&pg=PA53&lpg=PA53&dq=parnassius+smintheus+sphragis&source=bl&ots=AP4JFnkBfG&sig=xVpWVW4RKM1wCxwgM8idxeTyw8c&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi6jt7tnonXAhUD7CYKHec-D4w4ChDoAQgnMAA#v=onepage&q=parnassius%20smintheus&f=false|language=en}}</ref>
The bee species ''[[Macrotera portalis]]'' is bivoltine, and is estimated to have about 2 or 3 broods annually. During winter, individuals remain in diapause, in their pharate or prepupal stage. This diapause stage continues until metamorphosis in the next spring or summer, whereupon the bees emerge as adults. <ref name="museum">Buchmann, Stephen L. [https://desertmuseum.org/books/nhsd_bees.php?print=y “Bees”], ''[[Bees]]'', Retrieved on 15 October 2015.</ref>
The [[Amegilla dawsoni|Dawson's burrowing bee]] is an example of a '''univoltine''' insect of the order [[Hymenoptera]]. The brood of one winter will remain dormant underground until the following winter, and then will surface from their burrows to mate once, and establish new nests.
===Partial voltinism=== The term '''partial voltinism''' is used to refer to two different (but not necessarily exclusive) situations: * An organism wherein generations overlap in time, and so are not completely reproductively isolated. For example, in bees of the subfamily [[Halictinae]], one generation is produced in the early summer and one in the late summer, but males produced in the early summer may also [[Mating|mate]] in the late summer.<ref name="Seger">Seger J. 1983. Partial bivoltinism may cause alternating sex-ratio biases that favor eusociality. 4pp. Nature, 301:59-62, Available online: [http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v301/n5895/abs/301059a0.html]</ref> * (More commonly) a population where the voltinism is mixed, because of genetic variation (e.g., in the [[hybrid zone]] between a univoltine and a bivoltine area) and/or because environmental stimuli do not induce bivoltinism in all individuals (or across all years). For example, far-northern populations of the [[green-veined white]] butterfly ''Pieris napi'' are mostly univoltine, but some individuals may avert [[diapause]] and produce an additional generation under warm conditions.<ref name="Kivelä">Kivelä SM, Svensson B, Tiwe A, and Gotthard K. 2015. Thermal plasticity of growth and development varies adaptively among alternative developmental pathways. 13pp. Evolution, 69:9, Available online: [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/evo.12734/full]</ref>
==Evolution== The number of breeding cycles in a year is under genetic control in many species<ref>Coates BS, Sumerford DV, and Hellmich RL. 2004. Geographic and voltinism differentiation among North American ''Ostrinia nubilalis'' (European corn borer) mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase haplotypes. 9pp. Journal of Insect Science, 4:35, Available online: [http://insectscience.org/4.35]</ref> and they are evolved in response to the environment. Many [[phytophagous]] species that are dependent on seasonal plant resources are univoltine. Some such species have the ability to [[diapause]] for a large part of the year, typically during a cold winter.<ref>Hunter, M.D. and J.N. McNeil. 1997 Host-plant quality influences diapause and voltinism in a polyphagous insect herbivore. Ecology 78: 977-986. [https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20070417171443/http://www.arches.uga.edu/~mdhunter/publications/Ecology_97_Hunter&McNeil.pdf]</ref> Others that bore in wood or other low-grade, but plentiful, food material may spend nearly the entire year feeding, with only brief pupal, adult and egg stages to complete a univoltine life cycle. Yet other species that live in tropical regions with little seasonality may be highly multivoltine, with several generations feeding on constantly growing vegetation (such as some species of [[Saturniidae]]), or continually renewed detritus, such as ''[[Drosophila]]'' and many other genera of flies with a life cycle of just a week or two.<ref name="Schowalter2011">{{cite book |author=Timothy Duane Schowalter |title=Insect Ecology: An Ecosystem Approach |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2KzokTLIysQC&pg=PA159 |year=2011 |publisher=Academic Press |isbn=978-0-12-381351-0 |page=159}}</ref>
